segments.text: detachment of forward air controllers stationed at the main.
And there was a great deal of interaction, both radio and ground, between the American advisers to the Vietnamese, especially my group, and the facts.
They would, on occasion, we'd bring them out and let them meet the
and on occasion the Americans would go into Da Nang Air Force Base and talk to them on a social level rather than an operating level or business level, as you might think.
Because they felt and we felt that it was desirable for us to know one another.
and we became fairly close friends.
And they would many times stretch their capability in protecting us if we needed assistance.
On numerous occasions, we forward air controllers would
go in with fumes in their tanks after knowing that they had just enough fuel to make it back to their home Air Force base.
As long as we needed them and they could, they stayed on the station and were able to bring in either the C-130 gunships or what they call the fast-movers, the fighter bombers.
And on many occasions, I say that they saved lots of friendly lives by their dedication.
And they were not particular, whether it was Vietnamese and American advisors on the ground or U.S. Marines on the ground.
They stayed as long as they possibly could, so long as they could perform a service for us.
As advisor to the 51st Army Regiment, specifically, what were your duties?
As a battalion advisor, I assisted the battalion commander and his operations officer in planning operations, planning defenses, laying out the defenses that we felt were necessary in our home.

operational area we had a barbed wire enclosure where we where we lived we built those with our own hands with sandbags and lumber and barbed wire and so forth i was the coordinator for artillery and the united states
whether it be aviation helicopters or whether it be fighter bombers or gunships, the C-130 gunships I was talking about, the C-47 gunship.
I'm sure you heard the nickname, Puff the Magic Dragon.
Those were our responsibilities.
in our area of operation all the Marine artillery fire.
By that I mean before the Marines fired artillery fire within our area, they would call us and ask us if we had friendly troops within the area.
And we coordinated with the Vietnamese.
We would, for instance, if the

Marine battalion commander or operations officer came to our Tactical Operations Center to coordinate something, we would sit in on it and make sure that there were no mistakes about who was going to do what and where.
By the same token, if we, the battalion commander and I, are
My operations officer went to the Marine Battalion Operations Center.
We'd go along and make sure that there were no mistakes in communications.
We were, I suppose you might say, facilitators of communications.
We suggested to the battalion commander, I did, and later to the regimental commander and operations officer,
areas that it would be advisable to operate in.
We were also tasked for something that I never really cared for, but it seemed to be a fact of life, and that is attempting to persuade
a battalion commander to do something at the request of the regimental advisor or perhaps the court advisor, that we should do some sort of thing that they had not been used to doing.
We were his artillery planner also.
With all the troops there at that time, what do you feel was the impact of their presence on the Vietnamese society, culture, and economy?
The number of troops contributed significantly to inflation.
It contributed somewhat to the moral decay of certain elements of the Vietnamese populace.
It contributed a great deal to the modernization and Honda-ization of the streets of the major cities.
It did not favorably affect the Vietnamese civilization as such.
However, I don't believe that it harmed it as much as some might have thought.
Modernization, I believe, probably outweighed the moral decay and the modernization.
I really believe that it did.
You mentioned in your first tour that you were working, you were trying to develop cottage industries or to bring industry to the Montagnards.
Were you able to see at this point in time any results of that attempt, of the American attempts at industrialization in Vietnam?
I was never fortunate enough to be able to go back again to any of the places that I had been before, except the area around and just south of Da Nang and south of Marble Mountain.
It was actually a number of marble up-thrusts.
And the only areas that I was able to actually visit again that I had worked in before were the electricity in the south of Marble Mountain.
And I can't give you an answer that you asked for.
What did the men do in Vietnam for R&R?
Were the five-day R&Rs morale boosting or successful?
You're referring to the... Rest and relaxation.
The in-country R&R, I never took one.
I don't, and I never had the opportunity
to know anyone who really did.
I believe some of the Marines might have.
There was an R&R, Marine R&R area on the beach at the name.
China Beach?
Yes, China Beach.
I was there and it was, when I say I was there, that was where the exchange was.
and the Navy Exchange or Army Air Force Exchange, I'm not sure which.
There was one there, and I was there a few times.
I primarily went to the Exchange at the name Air Force Base.
But it was right next to the orphanage that I had worked with.
But again, it was off limits to U.S. troops by this time.
and I was in a different category, and I could not even go downtown without special permission from the, I guess, Air Force provost marshal.
I'm not sure who was in charge of the name, but I did not wish to become involved in an incident.
So I did not visit my friends for a couple of times during that period of time because they knew as well as I.
But I did get to see them on frequent occasions at the McVie Officers Club where this missionary, Mr. Smith, was able to come and get his mail.
And he was given special privileges because of his nationality and the fact that he had helped the friendly forces from time to time in interfacing with the local government.
Back to the R&R.
For instance, during my tour in 68 and 69, for myself and the people who worked with me, that you could see the different physical condition of the people when they came back.
And I know myself that the rest and relaxation was a tremendous
to renew the physical animal.
Where did they go when they went out of country?
As I recall, we had R&R centers in Australia, Bangkok, Hong Kong, Japan, and Hawaii.
There may have been more, but I don't remember.
I took my own R&R to Hawaii in 1968-69.
During the 1968-69 R&R, it was not as bad.
The publicity was not as bad.
in Hawaii because Hawaii is a military environment because of the tremendous number of military that have been there historically since prior to World War II.
It's been a Navy installation, it's been an Army installation, and it's been a Marine Corps installation.

population of the Hawaiian Islands, in my opinion, is heavily militarized, meaning that there are ex-servicemen, servicemen, wives, parents, relatives, and so forth, and probably would not  did not represent a true picture of the civilian world.
I think probably I did not, and I think you're leading towards something.
How did the exposure to the U.S. civilian affect the people who went on R&R?
And it did not bother most of us because we were not exposed to the screams of baby killer, criminal, murder, death, theft, and so forth at that time.
Not on Hawaii.
It might have been different had we come back all the way to the continent of the United States.
morale degrading thing.
It was a restful renewal.
Is this what was the stack arms?
Is that part of the program?
I'm not familiar with the term as being a program.
I know the term stack arms has been around the military for all my

adult life that i know of the military and it means quit it just means quit this whatever we're doing back home and of course you you do know that this is a command and it means exactly that you stack your arms and leave them for whatever reason and
How was your ability to communicate with the Vietnamese at this point in time?
And how important do you think it was?
By this point in time, most of the officers, if not 100% of them, were able to speak English.
And even though I had gone to language school,
a longer course at the Defense Language Institute to learn Vietnamese.
They seemed to trust their English better than they trusted my Vietnamese.
And I believe this was true with all of the officers that I knew during that period of time.
A few of them spoke broken English.
Most of them spoke grammatically correct, if not totally literate English.
They, with some few exceptions, they spoke with a heavy accent, but they were understandable.
My Vietnamese was poor, to say the least.
I was able to communicate with the lower-ranking individuals on a very basic level.
And in many cases, in fact most cases, dealing with the Vietnamese private PFC, it was a mixture of Pidgin English, Pidgin Vietnamese, and some French.
They knew, in most cases, some French, but I didn't know much French.
After we began to become acquainted with one another, we were able to communicate with sign language.
words that were common to both of us.
And as a last resort, I was able to, in most cases, write out in Vietnamese what I wanted or what I needed to convey.
I did understand enough
was able to write enough Vietnamese, even though my accent was probably atrocious, to convey simple thoughts.
What about troop rotation and command rotation?
Do you think there were too many officers in Vietnam?
Did the troops...
In other words, did the troops rotate too frequently or frequently enough, or were there not enough troops, or were there too many?
It's been said that there were too many officers in Vietnam.
Do you feel that way?
How did the committee rotate?
The officers that enlisted were officially rotated on the same schedule.
One year in country was all it took.
There was no particular problem that I saw.
The statistics, as I recall reading, was that the support base was tremendous in accordance with the actual troop on the ground.
But at the same time, you'll have to remember that this was a Charlie.
The aviation assets were used to support all forces, and we were supporting both the U.S. military, the Vietnamese military,

At least one case, the Korean military with aviation assets, and they are very much maintenance and support-oriented, meaning that for one pilot you're going to have 10 to 15, at least 10 to 15 people working on that aircraft and bringing in support, whether it be mechanics, armorers, or electronics experts.
I don't believe that the great support required in this particular war, or the support that we had in this war, would be much different from any other guerrilla-type war that we would fight.
Perhaps, yes, it was overburdened with service.

troops in only one area, and that was the area of comfort and supply, the exchanges and, of course, the amount of transportation that is required to bring in the beer, cigarettes, and nice things to eat.
But at the same time, it's what we were more or less used to and what we wanted, and the people in command
People at higher levels felt that it was desirable to do so.
I can't fault them for it because I personally took advantage of the comfort items when I could get them.
Realizing as you do that I spent that particular tour with the Vietnamese.
And without those comfort items, I don't know that I would have been as an effective soldier as I was.
Now, I will have to say that on many occasions and instances, I shared those comfort items with the Vietnamese.
And at the same time, they shared what they had with me.
I ate their rice and weeds, and they didn't particularly like my sea rations.
But we existed together.
Do you feel the reserves should have been called up?
Tactically, strategically, no.
However, politically, yes.
I believe that if the reserves had been called up, that the political situation as it later
I believe that the chain bondage of the world and of the United States would have been a
The fact that we fought this war with new conscripts, new draftees, and with regular soldiers was very distasteful to many of the political-minded people of the United States.
I believe that had the reserves been called up and possibly have shortened the involvement
that the political situation would have been different.
To what extent or how it would have been different, I do not know.
Possibly the dissatisfaction would have come along quicker and caused a more intensive effort, or whether it would have resulted in the people of the United States as a whole being stronger
behind our military, I don't know.
It's a question that I have no firm opinions on either way.
The last tour that you had in Vietnam was from December 1971 to 72.
You were the personnel and administrative advisor to 7th ARVN Division in 4th Corps ARVN.
What was the difference between being an advisor in the north and in the south?
The... Again, this was a totally different terrain.
In the north, we had some lowland rice paddy areas, primarily mountainous jungle.
In the
In the south, we're talking of marsh, swamp, and rice bedding.
Were the people and troops different?
The people were about the same.
There was a sprinkling of Cambodians, ethnic Cambodians, in the south.
quite a number of the soldiers were head of Cambodian.
They spoke Vietnamese and Cambodian.
And you could tell the difference by appearance.
Primarily they were less oriental and more Malay.
experience a little bit darker in complexion.
But I would say that they had a little greater hatred of the NBA, the North Vietnamese Army.
They were a little bit more loyal
appearing to me to the Saigon government.

Now, the people, in all cases, in my experience, had no great love for any government, whether it be the Saigon government, the NDA, the North Vietnamese government, or the Viet Cong shadow government.
As I intimated earlier on, they were loyal to their family, their extended family, and their village to some extent.
But one must realize where their loyalties were.
The primary ambitions of all the Vietnamese that I knew
except for the military, was to raise, grow rice, kids, and adults, and to have their rice bowl full every day.
That is about the epitome of the local peasant.
Leave me alone, let me grow my children, raise my children, grow my rice, and keep my rice bowl full.
And there did not appear to be much ambition beyond this, those that, the Vietnamese children that I knew.
The school teachers, of course, were wanting to impart their imprint upon the younger children and to educate them as much as they could.

the Vietnamese had a high regard for education, except for the very poorest and most backward peasants who felt that taking his working-age child away from him and putting him into school was not exactly what was necessary.
He needed to be out planting the rice or transplanting the rice.
And of course, this was a common occurrence.
How about the Arvin troops that you worked with?
Were they better or worse or any different from the ones you worked with before?
Again, we're talking about the overall throughout the division.
And again, the manpower base and the manpower pool is getting shallower still.
And again, we're getting people who are less well-educated, not well-educated at all.
We're getting the pest.
So the quality is deteriorating.
The overall quality of the new troop is beginning to deteriorate.
And I won't say that it was...
something that was terribly important at that time because in most cases it did not take a tremendous amount of intelligence nor education to carry a right.
We found that
We were beginning to receive nothing but conscripts, and none of them wanted to be there.

Again, as you probably have heard, it was impossible to tell by looking at a young conscript whether he had sent these towards the VidCon, whether he had sent these towards the Saigon government, or none whatsoever.
And we're talking about 1971 and 72, three years after the Tet Offensive.
Most of them would just as soon not be where they were.
They would prefer to be back on the rice paddy or back in Saigon or one of the larger cities doing something else.
They were a fairly effective fighting force if properly led, and this was always the problem.
As I may have stated before, they were not as eager, the officers,
in command were not as eager to pursue the battle because they knew that if they lost a soldier or a large number of soldiers that they had to bring in new conscripts and new people.
They knew that they were not going to leave Vietnam in 12 months.
They knew that they were going to be

military and with a long record of military service, they knew that their success in the military, and that was their chosen profession, though this time many of them they had no other, and they knew that their entire lives would be spent in the military, and that the loss of men was not going to reflect well on the
as well as the officers realizing and the NCOs, too, realizing that they were mortal.
Whereas many of our officers, the U.S. officers did not at that time realize how mortal they really were.
I'm referring primarily to the Lutonians and Captains that developed mortality only, or
realization of mortality only came late within their tour.
And sometimes even the second tour before they began to realize that, hey, I can get killed in this mess too.
Whereas the Vietnamese were thoroughly aware of that situation.
Do you feel that they lost their own home?
In effect, yes.
The Vietnamese lost the war and the United States lost the war.
And I can't place the blame on either the United States nor the Vietnamese.
I would say that the Vietnamese lost the war because of

corruption at all levels, starting at the presidential level, corruption favoritism, nepotism, because they were looking out for themselves and not even at the highest level did the officer or civilian official
really have totally the best interest of their country at heart.
They had always in the backs of their minds, in my belief, in my opinion, they were looking out for number one.
The United States lost their war for whatever reason.
I will very briefly say that the United States
lost the war because of lack of resolution to win the war.
And if you would like me to expand on that, it was a combination of the protestors, the very, very loud protesting minority,

and the lack of resolution to go against that local minority by our civilians and sometimes our military leaders, and allowing a sanctuary to exist across a black line on a map that does not exist on the ground, whether it be North Vietnam
across the border into Laos or Cambodia.

There were occasions, as you know, where those black lines were ignored, those artificial lines were ignored, and the U.S. pursued the NVA to their sanctuary and in some cases was successful in destroying that sanctuary, not totally.
It was the lack of resolution to destroy North Vietnam at the time that they could have been destroyed.
The bombing of North Vietnam could have been very successful had it been carried out
with a total effort, a total effort using what we had available, rather than a half-hearted attempt or as a warning.
You do, if you don't stop doing this, we're going to start bombing again, that type of thing.
The effort should have been, and I believe that

We could have won the war by, number one, Congress declaring war against North Vietnam, against North Vietnam for violating the CETO treaties, that is, engaging in warfare against our fellow treaty signers of South Vietnam, Laos, Cambodia, whatever.
had we declared war against North Vietnam, we would have then had the opportunity to actually invade North Vietnam.
I do not believe that such as North Vietnam and subsequently invaded South Vietnam, I do not believe that we should have tied our own hands to such an extent that we did.
I believe that a war once started should be pursued with vigor wherever the enemy is.
In your opinion, what way was the military responsible for the loss?
I want me to pin it to one particular thing.
Perhaps the measurement of success or failure of an operation depending upon body count.
Body count and the allied things that go with it
In many cases, the only means of measuring the only yardstick against which a commander was measured was body count.
And to me, being a more or less conventional soldier, I still believe in taking the high ground and hold it.
attack where they're weakest and defend when they attack and don't give an inch.
But this was not the manner in which the U.S. civilian government determined that we should fight and win the war.
And again, it was a
The thing that the United States military, I'm talking about all services, and the Vietnamese were more or less hamstrung in being denied the opportunity to go where they were.
When we knew where they were, we couldn't always go to them.
What did you think of defoliation?
I only had one opportunity, and before I was able to arrange my only one opportunity where it was needed, and that was at Camp Nandong in July of 1964.
I was going to obtain some decodient for the camp that was there.
And unfortunately, it was attacked and overwhelmed, and the camp was closed before I could get
The overall program of defoliation, I saw some of the results in the Delta IV Corps, and it didn't do a whole lot of good.
I was in and out of the areas before, during, and after the defoliation.
And while it took the leaves off the trees and killed the rice paddy and whatever, it did not result, in my opinion, of winning the war.
I don't think it lost it.
I think the idea was good.
But unfortunately, Vietnam is a pretty good place, a pretty good-sized place.
and it was just impossible to defoliate everything everywhere they were.
And I believe that it could possibly have been used with much greater effect along the Ho Chi Minh Trail.
I think it would probably have been able to have been more successful had we operated branches along the
the area along the  in Laos.

Had we done it in Laos, where the Ho Chi Minh Trail came into out of North Vietnam into the area west of South Vietnam, I think we could have probably devoted a lot more there of the defoliant, and it would have been more successful.
it would have probably made the Ho Chi Minh Trail more vulnerable to bottom attack and so forth.
Overall, what kind of military tactics were used?
That covers the whole spectrum.
From time to time, during
During the summer offensive in 1972, as I recall, or summer defensive, depending on which way you're looking at it, we had actual World War II.
